title-group.article-title: Pertinent reportable incidental cardiac findings on chest CT without electrocardiography gating: review of 268 consecutive cases

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Pertinent reportable cardiac findings on non-electrocardiography (ECG)-gated chest CT examinations have become easier to detect given recent advancements in multidetector CT technology. However, those findings are easily overlooked on routine chest CT without ECG gating given residual inherent cardiac motion artifact and non-cardiac indications.

sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: To describe and quantify the types of pertinent reportable cardiac findings that can be detected on chest CT examinations without ECG gating and evaluate how often they were reported.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p: Two radiologists retrospectively reviewed (blinded to the original interpretation) 268 consecutive routine adult chest CT examinations without ECG gating for the presence of pertinent reportable cardiac findings. Retrospective interpretations were then compared with the original radiological reports.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: One hundred and sixty-three patients (61%) had pertinent reportable cardiac findings. The findings encountered included: coronary artery disease (n = 131; 80.0%), coronary artery bypass grafts (n = 10; 6.1%), left ventricular aneurysm (n = 1; 0.6%), valve calcification (n = 131; 80.0%), valve repair/replacement (n = 5; 3.1%), pericardial effusion (n = 33; 20.2%), left atrial appendage thrombus (n = 1; 0.6%), cardiac mass (n = 1; 0.6%), and cardiac chamber enlargement (n = 29; 17.8%). On the original radiological reports 22.3% of the pertinent reportable cardiac findings, detected by the two radiologists retrospectively, were not reported.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Detection of pertinent reportable cardiac findings on routine chest CT examinations without ECG gating is possible. The high volume of chest CT examinations without ECG gating represents an opportunity for radiologists to comment on the presence or absence of cardiac disease which may influence future clinical decisions.

Cardiac CT with electrocardiography (ECG) gating allows for excellent evaluation of cardiac morphology and function by reducing motion artifact caused by the beating heart. However, recent advancements in multidetector CT technology have decreased cardiac motion artifacts on chest CT examinations without ECG gating allowing increased detection of pertinent reportable cardiac findings (1–13). Pertinent reportable cardiac findings that can be detected on current chest CT examinations without ECG gating include coronary artery disease, valvular abnormalities, cardiac masses, pericardial disease, and cardiac chamber abnormalities. For example, left ventricular myocardial fatty metaplasia status after myocardial infarction or pulmonary vein stenosis status post pulmonary vein isolation can often be detected on chest CT without ECG gating (14, 15). Recognition and detection of cardiac and pericardial abnormalities on routine chest CT examinations is important as it can impact clinical decision-making. Detecting the presence of coronary artery disease can lead a clinician to recommend lifestyle modifications or statin therapy for the patient in whom coronary artery disease was unknown. The exact incidence of pertinent reportable cardiac findings on routine chest CTs without ECG gating has yet to be completely quantified and explored in the literature.

Therefore, the aims of this study were to describe and quantify the types of pertinent reportable cardiac findings that can be detected on chest CTs without ECG gating and evaluate how often they were reported.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: Using our institutions picture-archiving and communications system (PACS), we identified patients who underwent chest CT examinations without ECG gating between a randomly selected 3-day period. All scans were performed on a 64-detector row CT scanner (LightSpeed, GE Healthcare, Milwaukee, WI, USA) with a tube potential of 120 kV. Using a pitch of 1 at a rotation time of 0.5 s, tube current was optimized by an automatic exposure control system (AutomA, GE Healthcare) and ranged between 120 mA and 350 mA. Axial images of 2.5-mm slice thickness, as well as coronal and sagittal MPR with a slice thickness of 3 mm were created. In patients that received contrast-enhanced studies, 70 mL of intravenous contrast medium iopamidol (Isovue™, Bracco, Princeton, NJ, USA) was administered at 2–3 mL/s. All non-pediatric patients (>18 years) were considered eligible for this study. Two hundred and sixty-eight chest CT scans were performed in the selected time period. These consecutive scans were then displayed to two radiologists in a blinded fashion for retrospective review.

sec.title: Image interpretation and analysis
sec.p:
Two radiologists (GC, AS, with 5 and 10 years, respectively, of experience in reading CT) retrospectively reviewed all 268 CT examinations individually, blinded to the original interpretation. Each chest CT was evaluated in detail for pertinent reportable cardiac findings (Table 1). Any finding that was in discordance between the two reviewers was shown to a third expert cardiac radiologist (SA, 15 years of experience) who acted as the adjudicator. Retrospective interpretations were then compared with the original radiological reports.

sec.title: Quantification and characterization of detected incidental cardiac findings
sec.p:
Between the two readers (GS, AS), there was 92% (246/268) concordance in pertinent reportable cardiac findings. A total of 163 patients (61% of entire cohort of 268) had pertinent reportable cardiac findings. In these 163 patients, a total of 372 pertinent reportable cardiac findings were found (Table 1). The most common pertinent reportable cardiac findings detected included coronary artery disease (n = 131, 49% of 372 total cardiac findings) (Fig. 1), aortic valvular calcifications (n = 69, 26%) (Fig. 2), mitral annular calcifications (n = 52, 19%), and pericardial effusion (n = 33, 12%) (Table 1). Examples of detected pertinent reportable cardiac findings are given in Figs. 1–6. Between the two readers, there was 8% (22/268) discordance in cardiac findings. After adjudicating radiologist (SA) review, the following types of pertinent reportable cardiac findings were in discordance: CAD (n = 2), pericardial effusion (n = 9), mitral leaflet calcification (2), mitral annular calcification (n = 2), aortic valvular calcification (n = 1), left atrial enlargement (n = 3), right atrial enlargement (n = 3), and left ventricular enlargement (n = 2). Of note, detection of a left atrial appendage filling defect was seen on one of the cases displayed to the third reviewer for adjudication, and not seen initially by either reviewing radiologist.

sec.title: Reporting of cardiac findings
sec.p: Retrospective interpretations were then compared with the original radiological reports. In 68 patients (25% of entire cohort of 268) at least one pertinent reportable cardiac finding detected retrospectively in this study was not described in the original radiological report. In these 68 cases, there were n = 83 out of a total of 372 pertinent reportable cardiac findings that were not stated in the original radiological report (22.3%).The most common pertinent reportable cardiac findings not mentioned included aortic valvular calcifications (n = 29), coronary artery disease (n = 22), mitral annular (n = 10), mitral leaflet calcifications (n = 1), left atrial enlargement (n = 1), left ventricular enlargement, and pacemaker (n = 1).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Pertinent reportable cardiac findings are easy to overlook on chest CT examinations without ECG gating, which are often performed for evaluation of pulmonary pathology, pulmonary thrombo-embolic disease, acute aortic syndrome, and tumor staging, especially as findings may be muddied by motion artifacts. This retrospective review demonstrated that despite inherent cardiac motion artifacts, it is often possible and very common to detect many types of cardiac abnormalities on chest CT examinations without ECG gating.

Direct and indirect signs of coronary artery disease, valvular heart disease, cardiomyopathies, masses, and pericardial disease can be suggested by routine chest CT without ECG gating. Evidence of prior surgery/intervention such as coronary artery bypass graft, valvular surgery, or implanted cardiac devices can also be easily detected without ECG-gated studies. Coronary artery calcification assessment on chest CT examinations without ECG-gating is an important task for the radiologist. There is a high negative predictive value and high specificity for coronary artery calcification as described by various studies (1, 10, 11). Coronary artery calcification is often easily seen on CT without ECG gating (Fig. 1).

MDCT without ECG gating can depict calcifications not only in the coronary arteries but also related to valve leaflets, mitral annulus, and aorta. For example, mitral valvular and annular calcification can be visualized and may indicate prior rheumatic disease and/or mitral stenosis. Routine chest CT examinations without ECG gating visualizes the aorta in much detail thereby enabling characterization of aortic valvular calcifications and possibly even aortic luminal narrowing (16). Extensive calcification of the aortic valve has been demonstrated to indicate severe aortic stenosis and may serve as a strong indicator for additional diagnostic work-up (17). Severity of aortic valve calcifications has also been shown to correlate directly with increased gradients across the aortic valve (18–20). As a result, the radiologist should report the presence of extensive calcification involving the aortic valve leaflets (Fig. 2). The reporting of mitral annular calcifications and aortic valvular calcifications may play a role in risk stratification, as presence of calcifications may serve as predictors of increased cardiovascular mortality (21, 22).

Evidence of ischemia or infarction can also be seen on routine chest CT examinations without ECG gating. In the study presented here, we observed one case of a partially calcified left ventricular aneurysm in a patient with a history of prior myocardial infarction (Fig. 3).

Although smaller cardiac/pericardial masses are not expected to be visualized on routine CT examinations without ECG gating, larger masses such as atrial myxomas can be detected even with less advanced CT scanners (23–26). Characteristics such as location, site of attachment, and possible associated valvular dysfunction may be suggested on images without ECG gating. In our study, we identified one patient with a left atrial myxoma (Fig. 4). On occasion, filling defects that may represent thrombus may also be discovered; in one patient of this study a left atrial thrombus was found (Fig. 5).

Cardiac chamber size and myocardial thickness may also be indirectly evaluated using chest CT without ECG gating. Although exact measurements may not be able to be performed due to motion artifacts and the phase of the cardiac cycle during image acquisition, significant chamber dilatation or abnormal myocardial thickness may also be suggested. Clinically important abnormal chamber size can prompt further diagnostic work-up for cardiomyopathies or valvular abnormalities. Fig. 6 demonstrates left atrial enlargement in a patient found to have significant mitral stenosis.

Our study demonstrated that up to 22.3% of cardiac findings were not noted in the original report on chest CT without ECG gating. The majority of the cardiac findings, found not to be reported, included aortic and mitral valvular and coronary artery calcifications. Implications on the early detection of mitral valve pathology, aortic stenosis, and CAD are important in these cases. It is not uncommon to detect incidental cardiac findings on chest CT requested to work-up and diagnose other conditions such as in patients presenting with chest pain where the clinical question is for the evaluation of pulmonary embolism (27, 28). Early intervention is possible and may alter medical or surgical management in these patients.

This study has several limitations. It was performed in a retrospective manner in a limited number of patients. A larger cohort might enable assessment if rarer cardiac pathologies may also be detected on chest CT without ECG gating and where variability may occur in interpretation of certain cardiac findings. The incidental finding that was associated with the highest number of discordant interpretations in this study (n = 9) was pericardial effusion. There is no current standard by which a reliable and consistent quantification of pericardial fluid on a CT examination without ECG gating is possible. Additionally, the effect and impact on patient management, outcome, morbidity, and mortality were not assessed in this study. Future prospective work focusing on clinical significance of incidental cardiac findings in management and patient outcome is mandatory.

In conclusion, recognition of pertinent reportable cardiac findings on routine chest CT examinations without ECG gating is important for early detection and proper management. Even without dedicated ECG gating, numerous cardiac findings can be detected such as coronary artery disease, valvular abnormalities, and chamber enlargement. As about 22% of pertinent reportable cardiac findings were not described in the original radiological report, an increased concentration on cardiac pathologies in interpretation of chest CT examinations without ECG gating in clinical routine seems to be mandatory. The high volume of chest CT without ECG gating represents a significant opportunity to make a wide reaching impact on patient care, especially if cardiac disease is detected early enough for appropriate intervention.
